DOC.HEAD: Famed Violinist Conducts Benefit for Decaying East German Cities
DOC.TEXT: In a benefit concert to help rebuild decaying East German city centers, Sir Yehudi Menuhin conducted the renowned East German State Orchestra as it performed for the first time in West Berlin. The opening of East Germany's borders Nov. 9 allowed East Germany's famous orchestra to travel easily to the great hall of the Sender Freies Berlin radio station for Monday's hastily arranged concert. For more than four decades, the 73-year-old violinist has taken his music around the world to play benefits, first for the Allied Forces in World War II, for fellow Jews who had survived the Holocaust and much later for German-Jewish reconciliation. In an interview during the intermission of the concert, which was broadcast live and could be heard in East Berlin, Menuhin said the time was past to think badly of Communists and that all should now focus on East-West cooperation. The classical program included works by Ludwig van Beethoven and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. Speaking German in the interview, Menuhin said he had last played in Berlin in 1929 as a teen-ager at the Berlin Philharmonic with the legendary conductor Bruno Walter. He said that the opening of the wall was a ``phenomenon which is very moving and unbelievable.'' ``Music has managed to get over the wall,'' he said. ``That is not possible everywhere, but you feel when you go to countries where people suffer or can't say what they want that music has a value that is hard to imagine in other countries.'' The centers of many historic German cities like Leipzig, Weimar and Jena have been ravaged by pollution, poor city planning and shoddy post-war construction. Menuhin joins other famous musicians such as Mstislav Rostropovich and Daniel Barenboim in staging benefits for East Germany since the wall was opened.
